thread.title: Abortion bills reappear in Michigan Legislature
thread.title_full: Abortion bills reappear in Michigan Legislature

author: Detroit Free Press Lansing Bureau
title: Abortion bills reappear in Michigan Legislature

organizations.name: department of health and human services

text:
Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email Abortion bills reappear in Michigan Legislature Lawmakers want no state money to go to agencies like Planned Parenthood that provide health care services to women Post to Facebook Abortion bills reappear in Michigan Legislature Lawmakers want no state money to go to agencies like Planned Parenthood that provide health care services to women Check out this story on Freep.com: http://on.freep.com/2lvbOwD Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. Join the Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Abortion bills reappear in Michigan Legislature Kathleen Gray , Detroit Free Press Lansing Bureau 11:21 p.m. ET Feb. 18, 2017 Buy Photo (Photo: Kathleen Gray/Detroit Free Press) Buy Photo 1 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
LANSING — It took six weeks into the new year, but abortion opponents in the state Legislature introduced several bills last week to advance their cause. 
Identical bills introduced in the House and Senate would prohibit the state from contracting with any agency that provides abortions as part of their mission. That would affect agencies such as Planned Parenthood, which the state contracts with to provide health care services, but not abortions, for women. 
It has been illegal to use state taxpayer dollars for abortions since the 1980s and the legislation introduced by Republicans will make sure that no state dollars will go to agencies such as Planned Parenthood even if the dollars are used for health care services other than abortions. 
The state Department of Health and Human Services acted as a pass-through to get $10 million in federal dollars into Planned Parenthood of Mid and South Michigan to provide family planning and other health services such as cervical screening for women. The contract was a $1.2-million increase from the previous year. 
Another bill would approve "Choose Life" fund-raising license plates as one of the offerings from the Secretary of State. A similar bill was introduced last year, but never got a vote. The state's fund-raising license plate program has shied away from offering politically linked plates. 
And a third bill would prohibit an abortion clinic from providing abortions until it got a license through the Michigan DHHS under more stringent rules that were passed by the Legislature in 2012 and defined abortion clinics as free-standing surgical centers. 
Other bills introduced last week include a repeal of the state's controversial fireworks law and a mandate that all schools provide all-day kindergarten classes for students over the age of 5. House bills 
HB 4195 : Provide for the conveyance of state-owned property in Marquette County to Northern Michigan University. Sponsor: Rep. John Kivela, D-Marquette. 
HB 4196-4197 : Allow local units of government to regulate when fireworks are used in their communities. Sponsor: Rep. John Chirkun, D-Roseville. 
HB 4198 : Require safety training for drivers on how to share the road with bicyclists. Sponsor: Rep. Julie Alexander, R-Hanover. 
HB 4199 : Increase the setback for gas and oil wells near residential areas. Sponsor: Rep. Jeremy Moss, D-Southfield. 
HB 4200-4202 and 4214 and SB 154 and 156 : Establish air pollution control, water resources’ and oil and gas commissions, give oversight over safe drinking water act to the water resource commission. Sponsors: Reps. Stephanie Chang, D-Detroit, Sheldon Neeley, D-Flint, Jeremy Moss, D-Southfield, Phil Phelps, D-Flushing, Sen. Jim Ananich, D-Flint, Sen. Hoon-Yung Hopgood, D-Taylor. 
HB 4203-4204 : Allow the Secretary of State to share photographs taken for official driver’s license, identification cards and concealed weapons license holders with the State Police. Sponsors: Reps. Beau LaFave, R-Iron Mountain, Triston Cole, R-Mancelona. 
HB 4205: Prohibit adoption of rules by state agencies that are more stringent than federal regulations. Sponsor: Rep. Triston Cole, R-Mancelona. 
HB 4206 and SB 155 : Modify the process for the collection of water samples. Sponsors: Rep. Sheldon Neeley, D-Flint, Sen. Coleman Young II, D-Detroit. 
HB 4207 : Create economic development incentives and provide funding for grocery stores to locate in urban areas. Sponsor: Rep. Andy Schor, D-Lansing. 
HB 4208 : Require that a state senator or representative who resigns or who is removed from office be prohibited from running to fill that vacant seat. Sponsor: Rep. Aaron Miller, R-Sturgis. 
HB 4209-4210: Increase the compensation for jurors. Sponsor: Rep. Peter Lucido, R-Shelby Township. 
HB 4211: Allow the testimony of witnesses who are experts on behavior patterns of human trafficking victims. Sponsor: Rep. Peter Lucido, R-Shelby Township. 
HB 4212-4213 : Change the requirement that law enforcement make drunken driving suspects driving commercial vehicles submit to a preliminary chemical breath analysis and require a court order before chemical breath testing of a minor. Sponsor: Rep. Peter Lucido, R-Shelby Township. 
HB 4215 : Allow unattended vehicles to run in a private driveway without fear of getting a citation. Sponsor: Rep. Holly Hughes, R-White River Township. 
HB 4216 : Increase the fines for certain violations of the Campaign Finance Act from $1,000 to $3,000. Sponsor: Rep. Michael Webber, R-Rochester Hills. 
HB 4217 : Create a Michigan veterans’ suicide prevention task force. Sponsor: Rep. Diana Farrington, R-Harrison Township. 
HB 4218 : Change the qualifications for direct care worker of a juvenile court-operated residential facility in a small county to completion of high school or obtaining a General Equivalency Diploma. Sponsor: Rep. Eric Leutheuser, R-Hillsdale. 
HB 4219 : Expand the deferral and dismissal eligibility for victims of human trafficking. Sponsor: Rep. Bronna Kahle, R-Clinton. 
HB 4220 : Provide for requirements and prohibitions of utilities’ use of so-called smart meters. Sponsor: Rep. Gary Glenn, R-Midland. 
HB 4221 and SB 162 : Provide for the prohibition of the state to contract for agencies that provide abortion services, which would defund agencies like Planned Parenthood for health services other than abortions. Sponsor: Rep. Steven Johnson, R-Wayland, Sen. Patrick Colbeck, R-Canton. 
HB 4222 and SB 163 : Create a fund-raising license plate for the abortion opponent Choose Life Michigan Fund. Sponsor: Rep. Shane Hernandez, R-Port Huron, Sen. Patrick Colbeck, R-Canton. 
HB 4223 and SB 165 : Create an African-American affairs commission. Sponsor: Rep. John Bizon, R-Battle Creek, Sen. Rick Jones, R-Grand Ledge. 
HB 4224 : Allow for the sale of event tickets at prices above or below face value. Sponsor: Rep. Tim Kelly, R-Saginaw Township. 
HB 4225 : Expand the priority populations for mental health services to include children who are place in residential foster care. Sponsor: Rep. Robert Kosowski, D-Westland. 
HB 4226 : Establish paid leave time for care of newborn or adopted children for certain employees. Sponsor: Rep. Robert Kosowski, D-Westland. 
HB 4227-4243: Create the budget bills for the departments of state government. Sponsors: Reps. Dave Pagel, R-Berrien Springs, John Bizon, R-Battle Creek, Kimberly LaSata, R-Bainbridge Township, Larry Inman, R-Williamsburg, Mary Whiteford, R-Casco Township, Rob VerHeulen, R-Walker, Tim Kelly, R-Saginaw Township, Chris Afendoulis, R-Grand Rapids Township, Sue Allor, R-Wolverine, Edward Canfield, R-Sebawaing, Tommy Brann, R-Wyoming, Roger Victory, R-Georgetown Township, Shane Hernandez, R-Port Huron, Aaron Miller, R-Sturgis. 
HB 4244-4246 : Repeal fireworks act, regulate the use of commercial grade fireworks, create penalties for violations and prohibit the use or sale of sky lanterns. Sponsor: Rep. Henry Yanez, D-Sterling Heights. 
HB 4247 : Enact a prohibition of reserving the mineral rights to property transferred by the state. Sponsor: Michele Hoitenga, R-Manton. 
HB 4248-4249 : Prohibit the use of drones within 1,000 feet of a prison, jail, law enforcement facility or court and establish penalties for violations. Sponsor: Rep. John Chirkun, D-Roseville. 
HB 4250 : Provide for mandatory enrollment in full-time kindergarten classes. Sponsor: Rep. William Sowerby, D-Clinton Township Senate bills 
SB 157 : Require the use of certain materials for water supply and wastewater projects. Sponsor: Sen. Rick Jones, R-Grand Ledge. 
SB 158 : Exclude used motor vehicle parts businesses regulated under the natural resources and environmental protection act from licensing and registration requirements. Sponsor: Sen. Rick Jones, R-Grand Ledge. 
SB 159: Provide exemptions of weight limits for natural gas vehicles. Sponsor: Sen. Tom Casperson, R-Escanaba. 
SB 160 : Modify the definition of an autocycle and motorcycle to include a motorcycle that is equipped with roll hoops. Sponsor: Sen. Tom Casperson, R-Escanaba. 
SB 161 : Designate the B24 Liberator as the official state airplane. Sponsor: Sen. Rebekah Warren, D-Ann Arbor. 
SB 164: Change the rules and standards for performing surgical abortions to include obtaining a license from the state Department of Health and Human Services and add sanctions of $545 up to denial of license for noncompliance. Sponsor: Sen. John Proos, R-St. Joseph. 
SB 166-167 : Provide for a requirement to run an electronic report on a patient’s prescriptions before prescribing a controlled substance and provide for sanctions for noncompliance. Sponsor: Sen. Tonya Schuitmaker, R-Lawton. 
SB 168: Expand the no-fault auto assessment on auto theft prevention to include commercial vehicles. Sponsor: Sen. Rick Jones, R-Grand Ledge. 
For more information on bills, go to legislature.mi.gov 
Contact Kathleen Gray: 313-223-4430, kgray99@freepress.com or on Twitter @michpoligal 1 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE
